bounty_table.description: This version of Capture the Flag is unique. There are no known vulnerabilities that will award you access to the flag; there’s no starting point, nor a guaranteed reward. You should only be submitting to the program if you believe you have captured the flag or are close to capturing the flag. Only valid submissions that detail the steps used to capture the flag are eligible to earn the **$1 million reward**. See the program overview for all details.

All awards are based on the **CVSS 3.0** scoring system. For more information, you can refer to the [CVSS 3.0 Calculator](https://www.first.org/cvss/calculator/3.0).

* The reward level is based on the vulnerability impact and increases for higher quality reports that include reproduction code, test cases, and patches. Rewards are not additive and are subject to change as we see fit. 3CX will determine the impact for a given security vulnerability based on existing and compensating controls. Prior bounty amounts awarded are not precedent for future payments. Our program's scope and policy is subject to change at any time and individuals are encouraged to refer to this policy often.
* Our rewards are based on severity per CVSS (the Common Vulnerability Scoring Standard). Please note these are general guidelines, and that reward decisions are up to the discretion of 3CX. While exceptional reports may qualify for higher bounties, there should be no expectation of a payout above the range baselines.

## Tier 1 - Acronis Cyber Protect Cloud, Acronis Customer Portal, API-s, acronis.work

The program is focused on Acronis Cyber Protect Cloud platform. We provide program participants access to our beta environment. To request an account, please follow HackerOne [Credentials](https://docs.hackerone.com/en/articles/8466488-credentials) guide and select `beta-cloud.acronis.com` asset. 

Note: functionality related to Advanced Automation within Acronis Cyber Protect Cloud is temporary excluded from Tier 1.

Acronis Customer Portal is available at [account.acronis.com](https://account.acronis.com).

The `*-api-*.acronis.com` domains and all subdomains under `acronis.work`. Please put extra attention to not harm services and users, as these endpoints are not in beta mode.

## Tier 2 - Acronis Cyber Protect

Acronis Cyber Protect is an on-premises cyber protection solution designed for business environments. [Request a trial](https://www.acronis.com/en-us/products/cyber-protect/trial/).

## Tier 3 - Advanced Automation, acronis.com, devicelock.com, 5nine.com, Acronis Cloud Manager

Functionality related to Advanced Automation within Acronis Cyber Protect Cloud, including API endpoints under /api/integration/advanced-automation/.

Our main domains hosting user-facing Acronis services. All subdomains under `acronis.com`, `devicelock.com` and `5nine.com` are in scope.

Acronis Cloud Manager provides advanced monitoring, management, migration, and recovery for Microsoft Cloud environments. [Request a trial](https://www.acronis.com/en-eu/products/cloud-manager/trial/).

## Tier 4 - Other Acronis Domains

All other Acronis domains, including domains that belong to companies acquired by Acronis.

Acronis Cloud Manager provides advanced monitoring, management, migration, and recovery for Microsoft Cloud environments. [Request a trial](https://www.acronis.com/en-eu/products/cloud-manager/trial/).

# Out of Scope

We do not accept reports of the following categories

- Ability to create user accounts without any limits
- Ability to perform an action unavailable via user interface without identified security risks
- Ability to send emails with no control over content
- Any activity that could lead to the disruption of our service (DoS)
- Attacks that require MiTM or physical access to a user's device
- Clickjacking
- Сlient subnets: 185.209.82.0/24, 69.168.226.0/2, 62.115.59.2/3, 195.122.180.224/3, 69.168.225.0/2, 193.163.203.0/24
- Content spoofing and text injection
- CSV injection without demonstrating a vulnerability
- Disclosure of non-sensitive information, like product version, file path on a server, stack trace, etc.
- Disclosure of private IP addresses or domains pointing to private IP addresses
- Disclosure of researchers' names, emails, phone numbers, etc. in disclosed HackerOne reports
- Domains previously owned by Acronis and its subsidiaries, but have not been used for over 3 years. The last usage of a domain can be checked, for example, using web.archive.org
- Leakage of sensitive tokens (e.g. password reset token) to trusted third parties on secure connection (HTTPS)
- Leaked credentials of Acronis customers
- Missing best practices in SSL/TLS configuration
- Missing best practices in DNS configuration (DKIM/DMARC/SPF/TXT)
- Missing best practices in HTTP headers without demonstrating a vulnerability
- Missing notifications about important actions
- Missing protection mechanism or best practices without demonstration of real security impact for user or system
- Previously known vulnerable libraries without a working proof of concept
- Reports that include only crash dumps or automated tool output without a working proof of concept
- Unauthenticated/login/logout CSRF
- User enumeration
- Vectors that require unpatched environment (e.g. missing Windows updates)
- Vectors that require browser versions released 6 or more months before report submission
- Executables: vectors that require paused Acronis Active Protection service
- Executables: password protected uninstallation bypass

# Informative

- Open redirects are closed as informative, excluding cases when redirect can be used as a part of exploit chain - for instance OAuth token leak and so on. In such cases, the whole issue will be rated according to the final impact and exploitability
- Ability to send emails with some user input
- Disclosure of JavaScript API keys (e.g. API key for external map service)
- Issues related to customers' infrastructure on hosting networks
- Broken links to unclaimed social media and similar pages
- EXIF metadata not stripped from uploaded images
- Local privilege escalation (might be triaged in future)
  - Windows: from admin to system
  - Linux/Mac OS: from admin to root
- Tabnabbing

We'll provide rewards to reporters who submit original, in-scope vulnerabilities. This table outlines the lower bounds for these rewards depending on the level assigned. Each report is assessed based on criticality, impact and risk to our customers and our company. Our minimum reward is $100. We may choose to grant bonuses or larger rewards to critical vulnerabilities, more creative exploits, and more insightful reports.

###Low vulnerabilities can receive up to $250 bounty depending upon the impact of the vulnerability and the team’s internal assessment of the report.


## Eligibility for Reward (Bounty)

As much as we want to reward every qualifying vulnerability in reports that come in, we need to adhere to strict guidelines in order to make our program sustainable. If a report does not qualify for a bounty, it can still qualify for reputation points. Our eligibility requirements are stated below:

*Monetary reward is awarded when __all__ of the following conditions are met:*

1. The report is a qualifying vulnerability (often just referred to as "valid")
2. There is a clear, verified Proof-of-Concept (PoC) of a possible abuse of this vulnerability on our system
3. You are the __first__ reporter of the vulnerability
4. The reported vulnerability affects one of the domains in Scope
5. No action under 'Prohibited Actions' was performed in the report

*The amount of reward is based on the following:*

* The severity of the vulnerability (CVSS rating)
* The likelihood of exploit
* The quality of the report
* Any other factor at our discretion

*Despite the eligibility conditions stated above, bounties will not be awarded if any of the following occurs:*

* We have reason to believe that our non-disclosure policy has been breached

We aim to pay bounties once an issue has been triaged. It is still possible for a report to receive a monetary reward even if it does not satisfy the stated conditions. This is entirely up to our discretion, and it is reserved for critical and high severity reports.

For the initial prioritization/rating of findings, this program will use a 4-tiered bounty structure for low, medium, high, and critical vulnerabilities. However, it is important to note that in some cases a vulnerability priority will be modified due to its likelihood or impact. In any instance where an issue is downgraded, a full, detailed explanation will be provided to the researcher - along with the opportunity to appeal, and make a case for a higher priority. 

## Our Special 25-50k Payout Tier:

Chia Network reserves this payout tier for critical vulnerabilities that qualify under one of the following requirements:

* The Chia blockchain health is severely impacted.
This includes significant dropping off netspace / nodes, hindering block propagation.
Transactions and or block creation stalls.
 
* Users' funds are at risk of being moved to another address without permission.
This must require no interaction of the user, social engineering attacks are excluded.

* Chia's primitives (NFTs, Offer Files, CATs, DataLayer, DID, VC/RC, vaults etc.) issues that severely impact their function.
For example a CAT can be minted or melted outside the intent of the creator.

* ChiaLisp weaknesses that can result in the issues above.
for example an issue enabling a DDOS attack on the blockchain nodes, or code behind Smart Coins to behave differently than intended.

GENERAL GUIDELINES

---

Please note these are general guidelines, and that final reward decisions are up to the discretion of Citrix.

Below are the types of vulnerabilities we are most interested in hearing about. 

**Critical**
* Remote code execution, e.g., code execution on CC production, remote code execution with root level access on host machine or multi-tenant key compromise
* Service key compromise, e.g., taking over a multi-tenant key

**High**
* Arbitrary account takeover of a user’s cloud account
* Service key compromise, e.g., taking over a single tenant key
* SQL injection, e.g., cross-tenant data exfiltration
* IDOR/missing authorization checks leading to key compromise or customer data leakage 
* Unrestricted XXE/file system access, e.g., cross-tenant data leak
* Directory traversal/arbitrary file read - depending on types of files that can be read, e.g., system file read issues

**Medium**
* CSRF - excluding on logout and on publicly available forums
* XSS - depending on impact and type of XSS
* Server misconfiguration leading to compromise or data leak
* Misconfigured S3 buckets - only when the attacker can weaponize the buckets/instance

**Low**
* Other vulnerabilities with proven impact which are not listed as out of scope

Extreme bounties are not rewarded based on CVSS. Please note these are general guidelines, and reward decisions are at the discretion of Crypto.com.

## Extreme Bounty Range: $100,000 - $2,000,000
Crypto.com, in our discretion, offers a higher tier of Extreme bounties of **up to $2 million** for in-scope vulnerabilities against our platform that could result in a significant loss of funds or a data breach. While we do not outline exact criteria for extreme bounties given each one being an extreme edge case, these are generally vulnerabilities that could result in a quick and immediate loss of over **$1 million** in funds to Crypto.com or our users, or that could dump customer PII en masse. Extreme Bounties might be paid in a combination of stable cryptocurrencies and traditional fiat funds.

#What we would like you to give special attention to:
* Site balance manipulations
* Trading/Purchase manipulations (e.g. trading with no balance)
* Unauthorized access to project servers (e.g. vulnerabilities that leads to RCE).
* XSS vulnerabilities on the assets with critical functionality (with proven script execution)
* Serverside vulnerability with information disclosure (e.g. memory Leaks / IDORs) of critical or highly confidential data 

Any other vulnerability that breaks business logic or can lead to loss of user privacy.

*Please be aware that our program is still new and we are still deciding on final prices.
The bounty can be easily increased in case a greater vulnerability is found.*

#Out of scope vulnerabilities:
##When reporting vulnerabilities, please consider (1) attack scenario / exploitability, and (2) security impact of the bug. 
###The following issues are considered out of scope:
* Disclosure of non sensitive information, such as project version
* Vulnerability scanners and another automated tools reports
* **OTP bypass (any other bypass) in KYC verification unless verification proven to be completed**
* **Reports of missed protection mechanism / best current practice (e.g. no CSRF token, framing/clickjacking protection) without demonstration of real security impact for user or system**
* Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) on unauthenticated forms or forms with no sensitive actions
* CSRF on self-hosted servers, unless proved to be present on public server
* **Attacks requiring MITM or physical access to a user's device.**
* Previously known vulnerable libraries without a working Proof of Concept.
* Missing best practices in SSL/TLS configuration.
* Any activity that could lead to the disruption of our service (DoS).
* Content spoofing and text injection issues without showing an attack vector/without being able to modify HTML/CSS
* Rate limiting or bruteforce issues on non-authentication endpoints (excluding [support.cs.money](https://support.cs.money/))
* Missing best practices in Content Security Policy.
* Missing HttpOnly or Secure flags on cookies
* Missing email best practices (Invalid, incomplete or missing SPF/DKIM/DMARC records, etc.)
* Public Zero-day vulnerabilities that have had an official patch for less than 1 month will be awarded on a case by case basis.
* Tabnabbing
* Open redirect - unless an additional security impact can be demonstrated
* Issues that require unlikely user interaction
* GDPR related issues (e.g. no account deletion after request, partially deleted account)


###Issues regarding response header:

`Access-Control-Allow-Origin: 'http://127.0.0.1:port'`

###With request using:
`Origin: 'http://127.0.0.1:port'` header
*(Also considered out of scope)*

GENERAL GUIDELINES

Reward amounts are based on Severity and overall impact and will be determined based on the table below. 
Databricks will determine, in its sole discretion, whether a bounty will be awarded. Reward amounts will differ based on vulnerability severity, as well as the quality of the report.

# 📊 Severity, Rewards & Reporting
*For the initial prioritization/rating of findings, this program will use the **new** [Glassdoor Vulnerability Rating Taxonomy](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1hP_ezL3GRuFpsdWFm-R0WWu3-0gWIJWSRufRF22vVbo/edit#gid=0). However, it is important to note that in some cases a vulnerability priority will be modified using the methodology defined below. In an instance where an issue is downgraded, Glassdoor will try to provide a detailed explanation to the researcher - along with the opportunity to appeal, and make a case for a higher priority. However, the final discretion remains with Glassdoor.*

When we are determining severity, the following descriptions are not meant to be absolute categorizations. Severity depends on **potential damage to the business and clients, ease of abuse, how much of the fix is under our control, size of the impacted user base, and sensitivity of the data**. Note: A high severity finding in a lower priority environment such as a demo application may be a low due to the low impact and non-sensitive data.

 When we are determining **rewards** within a severity range, the difference between, for example, a High-Critical ($7,500) and a Low-Critical ($3,000) would depend on the number of **prerequisites required**, the **difficulty**, the **impact** and the **likelihood of exploitation**.

For those reasons, we recommend providing:
- **An attack scenario:** what is the most likely way an attacker actually abuses said vulnerability
- **Clear, numbered reproduction steps**: if we can't easily reproduce what you are describing, we may misinterpret the issue or severity.
- **A video PoC:** for more complicated exploits.
- **Impact:** your understanding of the impact to Glassdoor or its users if an attacker exploits the said vulnerability
- **Recommended fix:** if you have any good ideas on ways to mitigate the risk without impacting normal users, it would be appreciated.

# 👤 PII Data
PII Data in our platform refers to data that readily identifies an individual on the face of the data *(e.g. a name, email address, phone number, national ID number, etc.)* If the data exposed includes this type of data, all the data exposed with it is also considered PII. However, if facially identifiable data is not present in the exposure *(i.e. it is not possible for a third-party to identify who the data belongs to)* then the exposed data does not constitute PII as exposed *(even if it would constitute PII within Glassdoor’s systems because it is normally connected to facially identifiable data).*
___
# ❌ **Exceptions:** Program Vulnerability Exceptions
Some types of issues do not present a significant enough risk to Glassdoor, and are usually not accepted. 
Any submission of these types will **only be rewardable if significant risk and impact can be demonstrated.**
 * Self-XSS
 * Broken links in Glassdoor blog posts
 * Publicly accessible Google Drive files without proof of explicitly sensitive info.
 * Sub-domain/Domain Takeover without evidence of exploitability (as compensating controls are typically applied to prevent this)
 * Vulnerabilities only exploitable on out of date browsers or platforms
 * Dependency confusion attacks without proof in the form of hostname and IP being executed on the system
 * Information disclosure with minor security impact (pathing, stack traces, etc.)
 * Vulnerabilities that require physical access, root accounts, or rooted devices, or MITM
 * Denial of Service
 * Missing best practices or reports without evidence of exploitability
* Leaked credentials **that have already been reported to us in the past**
* General Spam

Our rewards are based on the severity of a vulnerability. HackerOne uses CVSS 3.1 (Common Vulnerability Scoring Standard) to calculate severity. Please note, however, that reward decisions are at the discretion of GoCardless. Examples of issues that may be considered to be lower severity given additional context include: a reflected XSS that has a minimal impact (only works in some browsers, can’t be used to steal session information); or an RCE on an asset that doesn’t house production data.

We really value a well-written report submission. We will, therefore, award the higher range when a report thoroughly covers reproduction, provides remediation advice, and explains the full impact and any programmatic way to demonstrate this (where relevant, e.g., Python script, etc.).

# Rewards
Our rewards are based on the impact of a vulnerability. Please note these are general guidelines and examples, and that reward decisions are up to the discretion of the Hyperledger security team.

## Critical severity bugs - minimum [$2000]
Types of impacts that Hyperledger would consider to be critical include:
* Fabric Certificate Authority bypasses--all endorsers and authentication of who can and cannot create transactions that go into the blockchain rely on the Fabric CA.
* Preventing consensus--figuring out a way to stop the distributed system from achieving consensus. * Fabric uses a pluggable architecture for distributed consensus. Issues that can prevent consensus would be considered critical.
* Escaping from a chaincode container--breaking out of the VM.
* Unauthorized modifications of chaincode--changing the code that is executed inside of the VM.
Types of vulnerabilities that may result in these impacts include:
* Vertical authentication bypass.
* Recording unauthorized, invalid, or forged transactions in the blockchain.
* Amplification attack where chaincode generates malicious network traffic.
* Denial of service of the whole blockchain by stopping chaincode execution and/or the consensus network.
* Establishing a persistent beachhead inside of the firewall protecting the Fabric network.

## High severity bugs - minimum [$1500]
Types of impacts that Hyperledger would consider to be high include:
* Confused deputy attack on the Fabric Certificate Authority--mistakenly issued credentials to access the permissioned network or being re-issued another user’s credentials or otherwise affecting the permissions of other users.
* Taking down any Fabric component (e.g. endorser, ordering service, membership service, consensus network) through malformed data submitted from the outside via the API.
Types of vulnerabilities that may result in these impacts include:
* Lateral authentication bypass.
* Remote denial of service.
* Default configuration errors.

## Medium severity bugs - minimum [$500]:
Types of impacts that Hyperledger would consider to be medium include:
* Taking down any Fabric component (e.g. endorser, ordering service, membership service, consensus network) through malformed data and/or fuzzing of its API used for inter-service communication behind the firewall. If you fuzz from a privileged network position (e.g. behind the firewall), then the vulnerability is of medium severity unless you can show that it can also be triggered from an unprivileged network position.
Types of vulnerabilities that may result in these impacts include:
* General instability.

## Low severity bugs - minimum [$200]:
Types of impacts that Hyperledger would consider to be low include:
* Vulnerabilities found in demo/example configuration, chaincode, and applications.
Types of vulnerabilities that may result in these impacts include:
* Footgun attack.

# Report Assessment and Bounty Calculations

1. Rewards will be calculated from a minimum of $100 to a maximum of $10,000 or extra based on "Vulnerability Severity", "Affected Scale" and "Data Severity".

2. "Vulnerability Severity" and "Affected Scale" are classified into five grades according to the strength of the threat and the degree of impact on the service
tier, and "Data Severity" is classified into three grades by internally determining the importance of accessible data.

 
**[Vulnerability Severity]**

This table is a classification table according to the degree of difficulty of the vulnerability, and LY Corporation internally reviews it based on the information reported.

| |**Grade**                       | | **Description** |  | 
|-|-------------------------------| -|-|-| 
| | TRIVIAL ||  Bugs that are difficult to classify as vulnerabilities | 
| | LOW ||  Vulnerabilities with minimal risk.  **Example: XSS which cannot steal cookies** | 
| | MEDIUM ||  Vulnerabilities that can affect other users, servers.  **Example: Hijacking other user accounts, bypassing authentication, SSRF** | 
| | HIGH ||  System access through a combination of several vulnerabilities.   **Example: SSRF + internal API access + hijacking** | 
| | CRITICAL ||  Vulnerabilities that can execute arbitrary system commands.   **Example: Compromised servers** |

* Vulnerabilities of BETA/RC servers are only measured as MEDIUM at maximum.

 
**[Affected Scale]**

This table is a classification table according to the impact of vulnerabilities, and based on the information reported, the impact on other users and the size of the business impact of LY Corporation are internally reviewed.

| |**Grade**                       | | **Description** |  | 
|-|-------------------------------| -|-|-| 
| | RARE ||  Low-impact, such as cases that only affect you| 
| | SMALL ||  Minimal risk impact | 
| | MEDIUM ||  Impacts that can affect other users, servers, or reputation | 
| | LARGE ||  Impacts that could significantly affect other users or servers | 
| | HUGE ||  Impacts that can seriously affect other users and servers. Vulnerabilities that can cause secondary damage |

* Vulnerabilities of BETA/RC servers are measured as RARE.
* Impact ratings are based on internal review criteria.

 
**[Data Severity]**

This table is a classification table according to data exposure of vulnerabilities. Based on the information reported, threats to leaked data (sensitive personal information, financial information, medical information) are internally reviewed.

| |**Grade**                       | | **Description** |  | 
|-|-------------------------------| -|-|-| 
| | Normal ||  Data generated by general system-related data and services | 
| | Sensitive ||  Information that requires measures such as encryption or strict permission management, such as "User's private information" | 
| | Critical ||  Information that requires strict management according to laws and international standards, such as "personal identifiable information" | 

* Vulnerabilities of BETA/RC servers are measured as NORMAL.
* Data Severity is determined after an internal review of valid data (e.g., tokens,
keys, user information, etc.) among data exposed by a third party.

 
3. Speculative or invalid reports, such as reports providing results from the scanner, would be closed as "Not Applicable".

4. If the report is helpful for LY Corporation, in some individual cases it may be closed as "Resolved" without monetary reward, even if the reported issue is "Out of Scope" or "Informative".

Our rewards are based on the severity of a vulnerability. Malwarebytes uses CVSS 3.0 (Common Vulnerability Scoring Standard) to calculate severity. Please note, however, that reward decisions are up to the discretion of Malwarebytes. Examples of issues that may be considered to be lower severity given additional context include: a reflected XSS that has minimal impact (only works in some browsers, can’t be used to steal session information); or an RCE on an asset that doesn’t house production data.

Malwarebytes offers cash bug bounties for the most interesting bugs. The amount awarded for these bugs is between $50 and $2000 depending on the bug severity and exploitability. Additionally, the most innovative submissions are candidates for the Malwarebytes swag.

### Critical severity bugs (CVSS 9.0 -10.0)
Examples of issues that Malwarebytes would consider critical impact include:

* Remote Code Execution in Malwarebytes endpoint products with the potential to compromise end user systems.
* Remote Code Execution on primary Malwarebytes owned web properties
* Attacks that that would allow the takeover of the AWS based cloud infrastructure 

Types of vulnerabilities that may result in these impacts include:

* Remote Code Execution
* Vertical Authentication bypass
* SQL Injection

### High severity bugs (CVSS 7.0 -8.9)
Examples of issues that Malwarebytes would consider high impact include:

* Data corruption in Malwarebytes endpoint products
* Privilege escalation in Malwarebytes endpoint products
* Web based vulnerabilities resulting in unauthorized access below full remote code execution

Types of vulnerabilities that may result in these impacts include:

* Lateral authentication bypass
* Local file inclusion
* Reflected XSS resulting in session hijacking
* Insecure Direct Object References

### Medium severity bugs (CVSS 4.0 -6.9)

Examples of issues that Malwarebytes would consider medium impact include:

* Bugs that result in application crashes in Malwarebytes endpoint products
* Issues that would allow for bypass of licensing restrictions in Malwarebytes products

Types of vulnerabilities that may result in these impacts include:

* CSRF on sensitive actions and functions
* Reflected XSS not resulting in account takeover

### Low severity bugs (CVSS 0.1 -3.9) - no guaranteed payout: 

Examples of issues that Malwarebytes would consider low impact include:

* Cosmetic bugs and bugs with little to no user impact
* Bugs that represent a deviation from best practice with little to no security impact

Types of vulnerabilities that may result in these impacts include:

* Information leaks
* Directory listings

Our rewards are based on the severity of the issue and the criticality of the service or application. The bounty table lists the range of bounties we pay for vulnerabilities in our applications and   **does not apply to out of scope reports**.

# Severity Definitions and Examples

## Critical

Critical vulnerabilities are urgent security issues that present an ongoing or immediate danger to the users of our services and our infrastructure

* Remote Code Execution
* Authentication and Session Management Flaws (which lead to account compromise)
* Disclosure of secrets in publicly accessible assets
* Hardcoded credentials for a privileged user

**Note that Critical vulnerabilities found in out of scope assets are awarded in the range of $500-$1000.**

## High

 Typically, high severity issues are exploitable web vulnerabilities that can lead to the targeted compromise of a small number of users.

* Account takeover through Oauth misconfiguration
* IDORs that bypass authentication or authorization for significant actions
* CSRF on significant actions, such as changing email/passwords, deleting accounts, etc.
* XSS resulting in conducting significant action (i.e., not defacement, phishing, cookie injection, etc.)
* XML External Entity (XXE) attack
* Hardcoded credentials for a non-privileged user

## Moderate

 Vulnerabilities which can provide an attacker additional information or positioning that could be used in combination with other vulnerabilities. In addition to issues resulting from the lack of standard defense in depth techniques and security controls.

* XSS (minor)
* Domain takeovers supported by a proof of concept for `*.mozilla.org`, `*.mozilla.com`, `*.mozilla.net`, `*.firefox.com`, `*.mozgcp.net` and `*.mozaws.net` in addition to the list of sites in scope. If the domain is pointing to a claimed instance by another company, then the report will not be eligible for bounty.
* SSRF which leads to reaching **internal** network hosts
* Disclosure of sensitive information which does not expose the user or organization to immediate risk
* CSRF for minor actions.

## Low

 Minor security vulnerabilities which could lead to leaks or spoofs of non-sensitive information. Missing best practice security controls

* XSS (blocked by CSP)
* Clickjacking with demonstrated impact (Lack of clickjacking protection (XFO, CSP) is insufficient to claim a bounty)
* External SSRF

**Note that some low severity issues are not eligible for monetary awards based on their impact. We will recognize the reporter by thanking them on their H1 page.**

## Out of Scope
* We follow HackerOne's standard for [Core Ineligible Findings](https://docs.hackerone.com/en/articles/8494488-core-ineligible-findings).
* In addition to the [custom scope exclusions](https://hackerone.com/mozilla?type=team#scope_exclusions) listed on our policy page.

## Misc Notes
We have a bug bounty panel whose members decide whether a report is eligible for bounty and the bounty amount for eligible reports. The panel meets on a weekly basis, except for holidays and vacations, to discuss bounty decisions.

We have increased the value of our bounties.

Below is a brief overview of how we determine bounty amounts:
1. **Severity Assessment**: We use the CVSS score to categorize the vulnerability’s qualitative severity (Low, Medium, High, or Critical).
2. **Bounty Determination**: The exact bounty within the specified range is based on a combination of factors, including:
   * **CVSS Score**: The precise CVSS score influences the bounty. For example, a CVSS score of 6.9, at the high end of medium severity, will result in a higher bounty within the medium range.
   * **Exploit Complexity**: More complex exploits typically receive higher bounties, reflecting the effort required to discover and exploit the vulnerability.
   * **Report Quality and Reproducibility**: The clarity, detail, and reproducibility of the report directly affect the bounty. High-quality reports lead to better payouts, while poorly detailed or hard-to-reproduce reports will negatively impact the bounty.
   * **Impact Assessment**: The real-world impact of the vulnerability, including potential data exposure, business implications, affected user base size, and regulatory concerns.

## H1 Slack aligns to Salesforce bounty payouts

At Slack, our bug bounty program is a critical component of our security efforts, and we’re excited to announce that we have aligned to the Salesforce payout guidelines. While our prior program paid within a range for particular CVSS scores, the new guidelines pay out based on vulnerability type in addition to severity. In general, this will mean that our researchers receive the same or higher bounties for the same vulnerabilities. 

*Important note: All valid disclosure of PII issues are treated as critical. Such disclosure of PII bugs will receive a standard bounty of $500 across the board.*

We are so excited to be able to reward our researchers for all of your hard work!  Since the inception of our bug bounty program in 2013, Slack has rewarded hundreds of distinct researchers for thousands of verified vulnerabilities. Some of the best and brightest security researchers have contributed to keep our platform and our customers safe, and we hope that the bounties will: 
- Ensure continued engagement with Slack’s bug bounty program by paying bounties that are competitive
- Focus the attention of security researchers on the problems that matter most to Slack by paying more for more important findings
- Recognize the value HackerOne security researchers contribute to Slack’s security by paying more for their work

To learn more about Slack’s bug bounty program and to report a vulnerability, please visit our program page at https://hackerone.com/slack.

Tor
----

For Tor the tiers, price ranges and restrictions look like this:

### Low severity ($100 - $500):
    
This tier is for low severity bugs that force Tor to misbehave in a way that might be security related, but does not put our core users in danger.  If we receive a bug that is too low severity for this tier, we can still send the submitters some stickers or a t-shirt, and also mention them in our greetz list.

Bug examples:

* Triggerable undefined behavior (https://bugs.torproject.org/6827)
* Out-Of-Bounds reads (https://bugs.torproject.org/6530, https://bugs.torproject.org/15823)
* Security bugs that only affect highly-unused platforms (not Linux/Windows/Mac/FreeBSD)
* Security bugs affecting configurations which almost nobody uses.

### Medium severity ($500 - $2000):

This tier is for medium severity bugs that cannot be used to exploit or deanonymize our users, but can be used as part of a greater attack that aims to do so.

Bug examples:
    
* Remote crash bugs that affect clients, hidden services, relays or dirauths (https://bugs.torproject.org/14129, https://bugs.torproject.org/15083)
* Attacks that allow relays to link a user over different sessions (e.g CVE-2011-2768)
* Security bugs that require local (non privileged) access to the host to exploit (e.g. local privilege escalation to root)
* Triggerable memory leaks on hidden services/relays/dirauths (https://bugs.torproject.org/11649)
* Abuse of the onion service proof-of-work (PoW) system to inflate effort values or manipulate control loops, resulting in denial-of-service for clients or service operators.
* Resource exhaustion and other crash/hang/deadlock conditions in relays that can triggered by Tor client (mis)behavior

### High severity ($2000 - $4000):

This tier is for serious security bugs that result in users getting deanonymized or compromised.

Bug examples:

* Attacks that allow remote code-execution (e.g. CVE-2011-0427, CVE-2011-2778)
* Attacks that cause the leakage of crypto material of relays or clients (e.g. Heartbleed-like bugs)
* Attacks that remotely cause clients to de-anonymize themselves.
* Any means to bypass hidden service authorization.
* Any means to impersonate a relay.
* Any way for non-exit relays to read user's plaintext.

### Vulnerabilities in third party libraries used by standard Tor ($500 - $2000):

Medium or High severity vulnerabilities in any third party libraries that cause an issue as defined above are in-scope for this bug bounty program. This does not include third party libraries covered by other bug bounty programs, such as IBB. For the avoidance of doubt, this does exclude OpenSSL, but libevent is still in scope.

### Excluded vulnerabilities

This section specifies an incomplete list of vulnerabilities that are *NOT* in scope for this bug bounty program.

That's because these attacks or issues arise from unanswered research questions and not because of bugs in the Tor software. While Tor may attempt to defend against some of these attacks, any defense is a mitigation and should not be considered indicative of a strong security boundary. Other excluded attacks depend on users doing obviously unsafe tasks which we also consider as out of scope to this program and try to address by educating users.

Here is an incomplete list of excluded vulnerabilities:

* Tagging attacks or other types of end-to-end traffic confirmation using  packet modification or timing, such as https://blog.torproject.org/blog/tor-security-advisory-relay-early-traffic-confirmation-attack/ or https://blog.torproject.org/blog/one-cell-enough
* Website and Traffic Fingerprinting Attacks, a good round-up is https://blog.torproject.org/blog/critique-website-traffic-fingerprinting-attacks
* Using Tor against recommendations. There are several ways to configure Tor or use it insecurely including insecurely configuring it (e.g. setting  alternate Directory Authorities), leaking your IP address through  torrents, or opening downloaded files in external applications such as  document writers.
* Attacks that are possible by an attacker outside the software's threat model.  (For example, Tor assumes that the attacker does not have administrator access to your computer; has not installed a keylogger; does not control a majority of directory authorities; cannot make an authenticated connection to the control port; and so on.)
* When users go to the wrong hidden service address, they get the wrong hidden service.
* Timing side-channel attacks that can only be exploited at great difficulty, and only by local users.

For more information see as well: https://trac.torproject.org/projects/tor/wiki/org/teams/NetworkTeam/SecurityPolicy.

### Low ($100 - $1000)

This tier is for third-party/supercookie tracking issues:
 
a. Non-fingerprinting (identifiers/cookies/etc): $1000

b. Fingerprinting (Reward depends on accuracy and/or entropy. However, "fingerprinting" for this bounty program is defined pretty loosely. E.g. any bugs that help an attacker to find out something about a user's habit is in scope for this item):  $100-1000
  - No reward for browser version differentiation
  - No reward for OS differentiation

### Medium ($1000 -$2000)

This tier is for unexploitable crashes caused by Tor Browser patches and NoScript bypasses to get arbitrary scripts to run:
 
a. Unexploitable Tor Browser crashes caused by Tor Browser patches: $1000-$2000
  - remotely triggerable ones
  - indirectly triggerable ones by a remote attacker (an attacker succeeds in convincing a user to do certain things that crash the browser)

b. NoScript bypass to get any script to run $1000-$2000

### High ($2000 - $3000+)

This tier is for serious security bugs that may result in users getting deanonymized or compromised.

a. "Uncontrolled" Partial Proxy Bypass: $2000
  - E.g.: DNS resolution via non-Tor (https://bugs.torproject.org/5741)
  - Other non-Tor connection to an IP address that is not under an attacker's control (For instance STUN server, Mozilla.org server, etc etc)

b. Full Proxy bypass: $3000
  - Direct non-Tor connection to an IP address of the attacker's choice
  - Full code execution vulnerabilities not eligible for this bounty (i.e. c. and d.)

c. Tor Browser-Specific Code Exec Base Bounty: $3000
  - Applies to code exec vulnerabilities against our specific addons/patches/preference choices
  - Can only be claimed in cases where Mozilla's bounty does not apply

d. Bonus over Base Bounty/Mozilla bounty for code execution exploits that work in:
  1. Medium Security Slider Level on an HTTPS page: 50% Bonus
  2. Medium Security Slider Level on a non-HTTPS page: 75% Bonus
  3. High Security Slider Level: 100% Bonus

Privileges Required

Vimeo takes into account several factors both when determining the severity of a finding and when choosing a bounty amount. A few of these factors include:

- **CVSS Score** — the CVSS score provides an initial approximation of the importance that a particular security finding has for our company. However, CVSS often does not tell the whole story.  Therefore, when evaluating the severity and bounty amount for a particular finding, we consider the following three factors as well.
- **Scalability of the attack** — Does the attack affect a single/small group of accounts/ everyone on our platform? Could an attack write a script to exploit this vulnerability across thousands of accounts?
- **Business impact** — How does this attack impact our business? What specific part of our business does this attack impact? For example, a stored-XSS attack affecting our production environment might receive a higher bounty than an RCE attack against a staging environment. 
- **Difficulty of finding the vulnerability**— in some cases, we may pay more for some findings that require special expertise or involve chaining multiple exploits.

## ==_Time-limited activity_==
MiSRC “Surge Protection - Xiaomi 14 Mobile Guardian Program” is officially launched today!
We sincerely invite the world's top security experts to participate in this program and work together to protect the security and stability of Xiaomi phones.

**HyperGuardian - Xiaomi 14 Mobile Guardian Initiative**
**Event Schedule**
June 12th to July 12th.
**Rules**
The submitted vulnerabilities must be bound to the following rules. Validated vulnerabilities are considered real and effective within the specified scenarios to participate in the Xiaomi 14 Mobile Guardian Initiative reward assessment. The Guardian Initiative rewards do not stack with other reward programs of Xiaomi.
**Vulnerability Exploitation Requirements**
- The scope of the event is limited to the latest official stable ROM version of Xiaomi 14 series models (Xiaomi 14, Xiaomi 14 Ultra).
- The browser version should be updated to the latest version through the Xiaomi Mipicks App.
- The target should be in their default or normal configurations/system settings without any special modification.
- Do not apply for or use Accessibility permissions.
- The vulnerabilities must be unknown, unpublished, or 0-day vulnerabilities with POC. Vulnerabilities listed in the Chrome bug list are excluded from the eligible scope.
- All vulnerabilities (including root privilege escalation) will only be deemed valid once in all scenarios. If used again in other scenarios or the exploit chain, it will be considered a duplicated vulnerability.

**Qualifying Vulnerabilities and Reward Amounts**
The qualifying vulnerabilities for Xiaomi 14 Mobile Guardian Initiative is as follows. Other vulnerabilities not included in this initiative can still be rewarded according to the reward scheme at HackerOne.

|Vulnerability Description | Vulnerability Severity| Reward Amounts |
|:--------| :---------:|--------:|
| Remote bricking of a batch of devices(DoS attack), the device can no longer be used, and it needs to be flashed and double-cleared to recover |Critical |$27,600|
| Remote arbitrary code execution in the system process | Critical |$27,600|
|Exploit baseband vulnerabilities to inject and execute malicious code into the operating system|Critical|$27,600|
|Execute arbitrary code through vulnerabilities in near-field communication|Critical|$27,600|
|Remote arbitrary code execution in a regular user process|High Risk|$13,800|
|Remote silent installation and execution of arbitrary applications|High Risk|$13,800|
|Remote reading of any files in the APP sandbox| High Risk|$13,800|
|Bypassing the Android system's permission request mechanism to automatically obtain microphone and camera permissions| High Risk|$13,800|
|Bypassing the system-level lock screen password to unlock the phone| High Risk|$13,800|
|Bypassing the browser sandbox to execute arbitrary code| High Risk|$13,800|
|Remote acquisition of personal sensitive data files on the user's mobile phone (photos, audio recordings, videos, etc.)| High Risk|$13,800|

**Extra Bonus for Advanced Challenges:**
Exploiting an original 0day vulnerability to gain complete root access to Xiaomi devices in any scenario (excluding official root tools) directly rewards a bonus of $13,800, with the exception of vulnerabilities introduced by third-party foundational components such as gki.

**Vulnerability Reporting and Verification**
**Vulnerability Verification Process**
- Security researchers need to submit a complete vulnerability exploitation report, including:
  - A detailed vulnerability analysis report, including necessary call chain descriptions plus screenshots.
  - The source code of the POC or EXP to verify the vulnerability.
  - If there are multiple interaction scenarios or a certain demonstration effect, please upload a video record.
- The Xiaomi security team will reproduce the vulnerability under the constraints of "Vulnerability Exploitation Requirements".
  -   If the vulnerability is successfully reproduced, it will be confirmed that the vulnerability and attack scenario are established
  - If the vulnerability fails to be reproduced, a separate reward will be calculated for the valid vulnerability in the vulnerability exploit chain
**Vulnerability Validity**
- The earliest submission of a bug report is considered the first report. Only the first report of a given issue that we were previously unaware of is eligible for reward.
- In scenarios where multiple vulnerabilities exist in a PoC chain, if there are duplicated vulnerabilities, the reward is based on the non-duplicated vulnerabilities in the PoC chain. For example, if there are 3 effective vulnerabilities in the complete PoC chain, with 1 non-duplicated, then the final reward will be 1/3 of the full reward.
Note: If security researchers wish to verify a duplicated vulnerability with Xiaomi at an earlier stage, please provide your vulnerability snippet information to security@xiaomi.com before the complete report submission.

**Bounty Calculation**
**Reward calculation principle**
For each confirmed vulnerability, the final vulnerability reward amounts will be calculated according to the following formula:
**Final reward amounts = (basic rewards - duplicates deduction) x user interaction factor x impact weakening factor + extra bonus for advanced challenges (successful exploit as a prerequisite)**
The total prize pool for this event is 1 million RMB($138,000). If the final result exceeds the 1 million RMB cap, the rewards will be proportionally diluted.
**User Interaction Factor Explanation**
For security vulnerabilities that require an amount of user interaction such as but not limited to clicking on links, or triggering a phishing email, for the exploit to work, the user interaction can be divided into three levels: no interaction, weak interaction, and strong interaction, with specific factors and explanations as follows:

|**User Interaction Levels**|**User Interaction Factor**|**Scenario  Description**|**Typical Examples**|
|:--------:| :---------:|:--------:|:--------:|
|No Interaction | 1 | The attacker does not physically touch or operate the target phone and the user of the attacked phone is completely unaware |Message push, remote attack |
| Weak Interaction| 0.7| The attacker does not physically touch or operate the target phone, and the attacker deceives or induces the user to operate the phone (up to one time)|Induce the users to click on links (one click) or visit specific pages, phishing emails or text messages, network man-in-the-middle attack|
| Strong Interaction| 0.4| Requires the attacked user to cooperate repeatedly, or actively provide user information| Multi-step user interaction (two steps or more) |

**Impact Weakening Factor Explanation**
When a vulnerability is reported, we take into account factors such as the difficulty of exploiting the vulnerability, exploitation conditions, usage scenarios, and scope of impact. If it's really hard to exploit, needs strict conditions, or can only be used in limited situations, the actual damage it causes might be less than we thought. In that case, we'll adjust the reward based on the real impact of the vulnerability. 

|**Impact Weakening Category**|**Weakening factors**|**Scenario Description**|**Typical Examples**|
|:--------:| :---------:|:--------:|:--------:|
|No reduction | 1 | The vulnerability is successfully triggered without additional conditions | _ |
| Limited Impact| 0.7-0.5| Limited impact of the vulnerability|Silent installation of apps that are already on the shelf|
| Strict Conditions| 0.4-0.2| Requires certain conditions and has some difficulty in exploitation, not a common vulnerability| Additional configuration is needed besides the default settings, such as enabling dual apps, non-common vulnerabilities that only affect specific versions or models, limited code execution |
|Extremely Strict Conditions| 0.1|Extremely stringent conditions for exploitation, significant exploitation difficulty, and a small impact range|Requires root access in advance, and has a minor impact|

Please be advised that the examples provided herein are intended for illustrative purposes and are not exhaustive. The Xiaomi security team will exercise discretion in evaluating vulnerabilities, taking into consideration various factors including but not limited to the difficulty of exploitation, exploitation conditions, scope of impact, and usage scenarios. The team will make determinations based on the specific circumstances of each vulnerability reported.
**Other considerations:**
- The terms and concepts involved in this article are as follows:
  - Remote: Refers to exploiting vulnerabilities to carry out attacks without installing applications or physically touching the device, including through web browsing, reading SMS and MMS, sending and receiving emails, wireless network communication (excluding short-range communication with a communication distance less than 10 centimeters).
  - Near Field Communication: Refers to NFC, Bluetooth.
  - Local: Refers to the exploitation of vulnerabilities that requires the installation of applications in the victim's system or through adb, or requires physical access to the device. This type of vulnerability does not participate in the Guardian Plan.
  - Silent Installation: Refers to the process of installing an application where the attacker is completely unaware (Note: If there is a clear pop-up or prompt for a certain application download during installation, and the user can clearly perceive the download and installation behavior, it does not belong to silent installation. In this case, the Xiaomi Security Team will assess the vulnerability situation and adjust the vulnerability rating and reward accordingly).
- The Remote batch denial-of-service (DoS) vulnerability must not affect other users during testing and verification. If there is indeed a DoS issue affecting a large number of user devices, the vulnerability exploit chain and related details should be submitted in the form of a report for evaluation by the Xiaomi Security Team. (Note: Vulnerabilities caused by third-party foundational components will be further assessed by the Xiaomi Security Team. Rewards will not be granted for known or publicly-disclosed issues.)
- Vulnerabilities involving client and server interactions that conform to WEB layer business are rated according to the Xiaomi Hackerone WEB vulnerability scoring standards, and this type of vulnerability does not participate in the Guardian Plan.
- A complete POC (Proof of Concept) and a detailed report must be provided. If the white hat provides a simple or incomplete POC, and the final judgment is that it is a valid vulnerability, its grading and reward will be downgraded.
- Unauthorised disclosure of vulnerability details or submission to third parties will not be rewarded and will be subject to legal responsibility.
- The final interpretation right of this event belongs to Xiaomi Security Center.

Xiaomi is excited to introduce two new reward categories to the program starting in March 2021. These rewards are **_not time-bound_** and will run throughout the course of the program. 

## ==_1. Special Breakthrough Contribution Reward_==
**Effective from March 2021**
**Introduction**

As a special thank you for contributing impactful reports, we will conduct  a second comprehensive evaluation on valid vulnerabilities determined to be Critical severity. Based on the overall impact of the vulnerability to the business, **hackers may be rewarded an additional amount of _$1,000 - $8,000 USD_ on top of the base vulnerability reward.**

**Criteria**
Aside from the overall impact of the vulnerability, we will conduct an evaluation to further assess its complexity, the extent of the impact of the vulnerability (eg: number of users, type of users affected) and the novelty of the vulnerability amongst other factors.

**Introduction**

* Results will be tabulated after the first month and awarded accordingly in the second month, and so on.
* This additional reward will be awarded on the hacker’s most recent valid report for that month. Eg: If a hacker has earned $10,000 in bounties across 3 reports this month, they will receive an additional 30% bounty amounting to $3,000, paid out on the third valid report in the next month.

We will be announcing the results of our Hall of Fame every month, and the top security researcher in each month will receive their additional 30% bounty after. 

Good luck and happy hacking! We are looking forward to your reports.
